snp1.3:15.2: The exact nuance of this line is hard to pin down. Later Pali texts equate abhilāpa with “naming”, but it doesn’t seem to occur in any early texts with this sense. However lapanā is used in the sense of “flattery” in eg. MN 117:29.2.
snp1.3:19.2: Padumī is a word for “elephant”, after the lotus-like spots or mottles on an elephant’s body, or else due to their fondness for lotuses (padmaprasaktyā, Mātaṅgalīla); elephants are often seen bathing and eating in lotus ponds.
snp1.3:22.2: The reference is to the smelting of gold, AN 3.101:1.9.
